facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 90 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 90 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 5, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal from the Appellate Decree No. 915 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 5, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal from the Appellate Decree No. 915 of 1951.

facts.text: The plaintiff sued for a declaration that the property in suit situate at Mouje Digvale, a village held by khots in the district of Ratnagiri, was owned by him, was under his management and that the defendants had no right or interest therein.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff sued for a declaration that the property in suit which is situate at Mouje Digvale, a village held by khots in the district of Ratnagiri, was owned by him, was under his management and that the defendants had no right or interest therein.

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed title to the property on the basis of the sale of occupancy rights under the sale deed executed in his favour by Sitabai on February 10, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: He claimed title to the property on the basis of the sale of occupancy rights under the sale deed executed in his favour by Sitabai on February 10, 1945.

facts.text: Sitabai was the widow of Vishram Anna Shirsat, who succeeded Ram Raghu Shirsat, the occupancy tenant of the land in suit.

anchor.surface_text: Sitabai was the widow of Vishram Anna Shirsat, who succeeded Ram Raghu Shirsat, the occupancy tenant of the land in suit.

facts.text: Ram Raghu Shirsat sold the occupancy rights in the land in suit to Laxman Chandba Raut by a deed dated March 8, 1892.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Raghu Shirsat sold the occupancy rights in the land in suit to Laxman Chandba Raut by a deed dated March 8, 1892.

facts.text: By a compromise in a civil suit between the heirs of Laxman Chandba Raut and Tanu Daulat Gavade Sakaram, the heir of Laxman Raut got 3/5ths share and Tanu Daulat got 2/5ths share in these occupancy rights.

anchor.surface_text: By a compromise in a civil suit between the heirs of Laxman Chandba Raut and Tanu Daulat Gavade Sakaram, the heir of Laxman Raut got 3/5ths share and Tanu Daulat got 2/5ths share in these occupancy rights.

facts.text: Dattatraya Bhikaji Khot Kulkarni, a paternal uncle of respondent number 1, purchased the shares of these persons by the sale deeds dated December 14,1903, and February 13, 1904.

anchor.surface_text: Dattatraya Bhikaji Khot Kulkarni, a paternal uncle of respondent number 1, purchased the shares of these persons by the sale deeds dated December 14,1903, and February 13, 1904.

facts.text: On Kulkarni's death, respondent number 1 became the owner of the property.

anchor.surface_text: On Kulkarnis death, respondent number 1 became the owner of the property.

facts.text: Respondents number 2 to 4 are the tenants of respondent number 1.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents number. 2 to 4 are the tenants of respondent number 1.

facts.text: The land in suit is khoti land as defined in cl. 10 of s. 3 of the Khoti Settlement Act, 1880 (Bom. Act 1 of 1880).

anchor.surface_text: The land in suit is khoti land as defined in cl.  10  of s. 3 of the Khoti Settlement Act, 1880  Bom. Act 1 of 1880 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: It is not disputed that Ram Raghu Shirsat was the occupancy tenant of the land in suit and that he could not transfer his tenancy right without the consent of the khot.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that Ram Raghu Shirsat was the occupancy tenant of the land in suit and that he could not transfer his tenancy right without the consent of the khot, which, according to cl.  2  of s. 3, includes a mortgagee lawfully in possession of khotki and all cosharers in a khotki.

facts.text: It is also admitted that the transferors of the afore-mentioned sale deeds of 1892 in favour of the predecessor-in-interest of respondent number 1, or of the sale deed of 1945 in favour of the appellant, did not obtain the consent of the khot before executing the deed of transfer.

anchor.surface_text: It is also admitted that the transferors of the afore-mentioned sale deeds of 1892 in favour of the predecesror-in-interest of respondent number 1, or of the sale deed of 1945 in favour of the appellant, did not obtain the consent of the khot before executing the deed of transfer.

facts.text: The plaintiff alleged that the sale deed in favour of respondent number 1 was void and that therefore he had title to the suit land on the basis of the sale deed in his favour.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff alleged that the sale deed in favour of respondent number 1 was void and that therefore he had title to the suit land on the basis of the sale deed in his favour.

facts.text: Respondent number 1 contended that Ram Raghu Shirsat lost his rights in the property in suit after he had executed the sale deed on March 8, 1892, and that, therefore the plaintiff obtained no title on the basis of the sale deed in his favour.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent number 1 contended that Ram Raghu Shirsat lost his rights in the property in suit after he had executed the sale deed on March 8, 1892, and that, therefore the plaintiff obtained no title on the basis of the sale deed in his favour.

facts.text: The trial Court held the sale deed of 1892 to be good sale deed and binding on the plaintiff and dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held the sale deed of 1892 to be good sale deed and binding on the plaintiff and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: On appeal, the Assistant Judge reversed the decree and decreed the suit holding that a transfer of the occupancy rights in the suit lands by Ram Raghu Shirsat in favour of Laxman Raut was void.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Assistant Judge reversed the decree and decreed the suit holding that a transfer of the occupancy rights in the suit lands by Ram Raghu Sirsat in favour of Laxman Raut was void and that the plaintiff obtained good title under the sale deed in his favour in view of the amendment of s. 9 of the Act by s. 31 of the Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939 (Act XXIX of 1939), by which no consent of the khot was necessary for executing the sale deed in 1945.

facts.text: Respondent number 1 preferred a second appeal to the High Court which set aside the decree of the Assistant Judge and restoring the decree of the trial Court, dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent number 1 preferred a second appeal to the High Court which set aside the decree of the Assistant Judge and restoring the decree of the trial Court, dismissed the suit.

facts.text: The Bombay Tenancy Act received assent of the Governor of Bombay on April 2, 1940, but it came into force in April 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Tenancy Act received assent of the Governor of Bombay on April 2, 1940, but it came into force in April 1946 when the Government issued the necessary notification in exercise of the powers conferred under sub-s. (3) of s. 1 of that Act.

facts.text: Section 31 of the Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939, made amendments to S. 9 of the Act and the section after amendment reads: The rights of khots and privileged occupants shall be heritable and transferable.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has no force. Section 31 of the Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939, made amendments to S. 9 of the Act and the section after amendment reads The rights of khots and privileged occupants shall be heritable and transferable.

facts.text: s. 9, as it stood on February 10, 1945, when Sitabai executed the sale deed in favour of the appellant, made the rights of permanent tenants not transferable without the consent of the khot.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear therefore that s. 9, as it stood on February 10, 1945, when Sitabai executed the sale deed in favour of the appellant, made the rights of permanent tenants not transferable without the consent of the khot, and that therefore the sale in favour of the appellant was as much hit adversely by the provisions of s. 9 of the Act as the sale of the land in suit in favour of the predecessor-in-interest of respondent number 1.

facts.text: The High Court held that the sale deed in favour of the plaintiff too would be hit by the provisions of s.9 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It held that the sale deed in favour- of the plaintiff too would be hit by the provisions of s.9 of the Act.

facts.text: The plaintiff has no title whether a transfer by a permanent tenant without the consent of the khot be void or voidable.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff has no title whether a transfer by a permanent tenant without the consent of the khot be void or voidable.

facts.text: The dismissal of his suit is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The dismissal of his suit is therefore correct.

arguments.claim: Bombay Tenancy Act came into force in April 1946; s.9 as stood on February 10, 1945 required khot consent for transfer making 1945 sale invalid like 1892 sale.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Tenancy Act received assent of the Governor of Bombay on April 2, 1940, but it came into force in April 1946 when the Government issued the necessary numberification in exercise of the powers companyferred under subs. (3) of s. 1 of that Act. It is clear therefore that s. 9, as it stood on February 10, 1945, when Sitabai executed the sale deed in favour of the appellant, made the rights of permanent tenants numbertransferable without the companysent of the khot, and that therefore the sale in favour of the appellant was as much hit adversely by the provisions of s. 9 of the Act as the sale of the land in suit in favour of the predecessor-in-interest of respondent number 1.
